Violation_Type: Denial of refugee claim based on flawed fact-finding and procedural unfairness
Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal's decision was based on credible evidence and a fair process
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Application_Facts: Fungai Nyoka fled Zimbabwe due to alleged persecution by ZANU-PF for her MDC involvement; claimed fear of future persecution
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal denied refugee claim based on credibility findings and lack of well-founded fear
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the tribunal's decision
Court_Ruling: Judicial review allowed; tribunal's decision quashed
Defendant_Behavior: Tribunal discredited testimony based on alleged contradictions, including on ZANU-PF militia formation date
Grounds_for_Claim: Past persecution and well-founded fear of future persecution due to political opinion
Legal_Standard: Credible evidence of past persecution or well-founded fear of future persecution under IRPA s. 96 and s. 97
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of testimony, country conditions in Zimbabwe, consistency of evidence
Procedural_Issue: Failure to uphold natural justice, inadequate consideration of relevant evidence
Review_Standard: Reasonableness, with correctness for questions of law
Credibility_Assessment: Tribunal found inconsistencies in testimony, particularly regarding ZANU-PF militia timeline
Evidence_Used: Nyoka’s testimony, tribunal's prior findings on country conditions
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to political affiliation with MDC in Zimbabwe
Evidence_Assessed: Testimony of Nyoka, official country reports (inadequately considered)
Relief_Sought: Overturning of tribunal decision and remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: A well-founded fear of persecution must be supported by credible evidence and assessed fairly under IRPA
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal failed to consider new contradictory evidence and relevant country conditions
Outcome: Decision quashed, case remitted to a different panel for re-determination
Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) / Refugee Protection Division
Harm_Assessment: Risk of return to persecution in Zimbabwe due to political activities
Cause_Description: Nyoka fled Zimbabwe after facing threats and harm due to her involvement with the opposition MDC party
Evidence_Handling: New evidence admitted by Federal Court contradicted tribunal’s factual assumptions
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections 96 and 97, principles of natural justice
Evidence_Issues: Contradictions in tribunal’s reliance on facts not supported by evidence; failure to assess key evidence
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, ss. 96, 97
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to conduct judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Tribunal’s assessment deemed unreasonable due to ignoring new and relevant evidence
Decision_Rationale: Errors in fact-finding, lack of proper s. 97 analysis, breach of procedural fairness
Decision_Making_Body: Refugee Protection Division of the IRB
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider new evidence, reliance on incorrect factual premises
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 96 IRPA, objective basis under s. 97
